title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. The risk of conflicts arises when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. Corporate political spending has increased significantly since the Citizens United decision in 2010. Contributions to certain entities do not require public disclosure. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting donations to political action committees or entities under section 501(c)(4) or 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. Conflicts of interest can be addressed through public disclosure to the Office of Government Ethics. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. Definitions in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 are amended to include the term 'covered contribution' as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization or specific types of organizations. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a 'covered contribution' as a payment made by or on behalf of a covered individual to certain organizations. This includes contributions exempt from tax under the Internal Revenue Code and those that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations relevant to the agency where the individual is nominated or serving. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a 'covered contribution' as a payment solicited in writing by or on behalf of a covered individual, subject to Federal laws or regulations administered by the agency where the individual is nominated or serving, and made to a political organization or certain tax-exempt organizations. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a 'covered contribution' as a payment made to a tax-exempt organization described in specific clauses, with a total amount not less than the contribution limitation set by the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. A 'covered individual' is someone nominated or appointed to a covered position. A 'covered individual' is an individual nominated or appointed to a covered position, which includes positions in specific levels of the Executive Schedule, Senior Executive Service, and confidential or policy-determining positions in the executive branch. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to include disclosure requirements for individuals in covered positions, excluding those excluded from certain sections. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to include disclosure requirements for individuals in covered positions, with specific details on reporting obligations when transitioning between positions. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to include disclosure requirements for individuals in covered positions, with specific details on reporting obligations when transitioning between positions. The amendment includes definitions for terms like "applicable period" and "covered gift" in relation to political campaign funds. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 now requires covered individuals to report covered contributions, including details like dates, value, and parties involved. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 mandates covered individuals to disclose covered contributions, including donor and recipient names. Contributions made by or on behalf of a covered individual may pose a conflict of interest, but exemptions can be granted by the Director of the Office of Government Ethics. Reports filed by covered individuals must include information on received gifts. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 requires covered individuals to disclose contributions and gifts received. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics must provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress upon request. Rules on ethics agreements for agency appointments will be issued promptly. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to make technical and conforming changes related to ethics agreements between agencies and appointed individuals. This includes adjustments to specific sections within the Act. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to make technical changes related to ethics agreements between agencies and appointed individuals, including adjustments to specific sections within the Act such as section 109(15), 109(16), and 109(11). Amendments are also made to the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Amendments are made to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, specifically adjusting sections related to ethics agreements. Changes include updating references to specific sections within the Act.
